an10.155:1.1.pli: “Dasahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato puggalo na sevitabbo.
an10.155:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, you should not associate with an individual who has ten qualities.

an10.155:1.3.pli: Micchādiṭṭhiko hoti, micchāsaṅkappo hoti, micchāvāco hoti, micchākammanto hoti, micchāājīvo hoti, micchāvāyāmo hoti, micchāsati hoti, micchāsamādhi hoti, micchāñāṇī hoti, micchāvimutti hoti—
an10.155:1.3.eng: Wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, wrong immersion, wrong knowledge, and wrong freedom.

an10.155:1.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, dasahi dhammehi samannāgato puggalo na sevitabbo.
an10.155:1.4.eng: You should not associate with an individual who has these ten qualities.

an10.155:2.1.pli: Dasahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato puggalo sevitabbo.
an10.155:2.1.eng: You should associate with an individual who has ten qualities.

an10.155:2.3.pli: Sammādiṭṭhiko hoti, sammāsaṅkappo hoti, sammāvāco hoti, sammākammanto hoti, sammāājīvo hoti, sammāvāyāmo hoti, sammāsati hoti, sammāsamādhi hoti, sammāñāṇī hoti, sammāvimutti hoti—
an10.155:2.3.eng: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.

an10.155:2.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, dasahi dhammehi samannāgato puggalo sevitabbo”ti.
an10.155:2.4.eng: You should associate with an individual who has these ten qualities.”

an10.156-166:1.1.pli: “Dasahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato puggalo na bhajitabbo …pe…
an10.156-166:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, you should not frequent an individual who has ten qualities. …

an10.156-166:2.4.pli: Sammādiṭṭhiko hoti, sammāsaṅkappo hoti, sammāvāco hoti, sammākammanto hoti, sammāājīvo hoti, sammāvāyāmo hoti, sammāsati hoti, sammāsamādhi hoti, sammāñāṇī hoti, sammāvimutti hoti—
an10.156-166:2.4.eng: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.

an10.156-166:2.5.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, dasahi dhammehi samannāgato puggalo bahuṃ puññaṃ pasavatī”ti.
an10.156-166:2.5.eng: An individual who has these ten qualities creates much merit.”

an10.16:0.3.eng: Worthy of Offerings Dedicated to the Gods

an10.16:1.1.pli: “Dasayime, bhikkhave, puggalā āhuneyyā pāhuneyyā dakkhiṇeyyā añjalikaraṇīyā anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
an10.16:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these ten individuals are worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and are the supreme field of merit for the world.

an10.16:1.3.pli: Tathāgato arahaṃ sammāsambuddho, paccekabuddho, ubhatobhāgavimutto, paññāvimutto, kāyasakkhī, diṭṭhippatto, saddhāvimutto, saddhānusārī, dhammānusārī, gotrabhū—
an10.16:1.3.eng: A Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha; an Independent Buddha; one freed both ways; one freed by wisdom; a direct witness; one attained to view; one freed by faith; a follower by faith; a follower of teachings; a lamb of the flock.

an10.16:1.4.pli: ime kho, bhikkhave, dasa puggalā āhuneyyā …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā”ti.
an10.16:1.4.eng: These are the ten individuals who are worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and are the supreme field of merit for the world.”

an10.167:1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo tadahuposathe sīsaṃnhāto navaṃ khomayugaṃ nivattho allakusamuṭṭhiṃ ādāya bhagavato avidūre ekamantaṃ ṭhito hoti.
an10.167:1.1.eng: Now, at that time it was the sabbath. The brahmin Jānussoṇi had bathed his head and dressed in a new pair of linen robes. Holding a handful of fresh grass, he stood to one side not far from the Buddha.

an10.167:2.1.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā jāṇussoṇiṃ brāhmaṇaṃ tadahuposathe sīsaṃnhātaṃ navaṃ khomayugaṃ nivatthaṃ allakusamuṭṭhiṃ ādāya ekamantaṃ ṭhitaṃ.

an10.167:2.3.pli: “kiṃ nu tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, tadahuposathe sīsaṃnhāto navaṃ khomayugaṃ nivattho allakusamuṭṭhiṃ ādāya ekamantaṃ ṭhito?
an10.167:2.3.eng: “Brahmin, why have you bathed your head and dressed in a new pair of linen robes? Why are you standing to one side holding a handful of fresh grass?

an10.167:2.4.eng: What’s going on today with the brahmin clan?”

an10.167:2.5.eng: “Worthy Gotama, today is the ceremony of descent for the brahmin clan.”

an10.167:3.1.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana, brāhmaṇa, brāhmaṇānaṃ paccorohaṇī hotī”ti?
an10.167:3.1.eng: “But how do the brahmins observe the ceremony of descent?”

an10.167:3.2.pli: “Idha, bho gotama, brāhmaṇā tadahuposathe sīsaṃnhātā navaṃ khomayugaṃ nivatthā allena gomayena pathaviṃ opuñjitvā haritehi kusehi pattharitvā antarā ca velaṃ antarā ca agyāgāraṃ seyyaṃ kappenti.
an10.167:3.2.eng: “Well, worthy Gotama, on the sabbath the brahmins bathe their heads and dress in a new pair of linen robes. They make a heap of fresh cow dung and spread it with green grass. Then they make their beds between the boundary and the fire chamber.

an10.167:3.3.pli: Te taṃ rattiṃ tikkhattuṃ paccuṭṭhāya pañjalikā aggiṃ namassanti:
an10.167:3.3.eng: That night they rise three times and worship the fire with joined palms:

an10.167:3.5.eng: And they serve the fire with abundant ghee, oil, and butter.

an10.167:3.6.pli: Tassā ca rattiyā accayena paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena brāhmaṇe santappenti.
an10.167:3.6.eng: And when the night has passed they serve the brahmins with delicious fresh and cooked foods.

an10.167:3.7.pli: Evaṃ, bho gotama, brāhmaṇānaṃ paccorohaṇī hotī”ti.
an10.167:3.7.eng: That’s how the brahmins observe the ceremony of descent.”

an10.167:4.1.pli: “Aññathā kho, brāhmaṇa, brāhmaṇānaṃ paccorohaṇī hoti, aññathā ca pana ariyassa vinaye paccorohaṇī hotī”ti.
an10.167:4.1.eng: “The ceremony of descent observed by the brahmins is quite different from that observed in the training of the Noble One.”

an10.167:4.2.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana, bho gotama, ariyassa vinaye paccorohaṇī hoti?
an10.167:4.2.eng: “But worthy Gotama, how is the ceremony of descent observed in the training of the Noble One?

an10.167:4.3.pli: Sādhu me bhavaṃ gotamo tathā dhammaṃ desetu yathā ariyassa vinaye paccorohaṇī hotī”ti.
an10.167:4.3.eng: Worthy Gotama, please teach me this.”

an10.167:5.1.pli: “Tena hi, brāhmaṇa, suṇāhi, sādhukaṃ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
an10.167:5.1.eng: “Well then, brahmin, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

an10.167:5.2.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo bhagavato paccassosi.

an10.167:6.2.pli: ‘pāṇātipātassa kho pāpako vipāko diṭṭhe ceva dhamme abhisamparāyañcā’ti.
an10.167:6.2.eng: ‘Killing living creatures has a bad result in the present life and in lives to come.’

an10.167:6.3.eng: Reflecting like this, they give up killing living creatures,

an10.167:6.4.eng: they descend from killing living creatures.

an10.167:7.2.eng: in the present life and in lives to come.’

an10.167:7.3.eng: Reflecting like this, they give up stealing,

an10.167:8.2.eng: in the present life and in lives to come.’

an10.167:8.3.eng: Reflecting like this, they give up sexual misconduct,

an10.167:9.2.eng: in the present life and in lives to come.’

an10.167:9.3.eng: Reflecting like this, they give up lying,

an10.167:10.2.eng: in the present life and in lives to come.’

an10.167:10.3.pli: So iti paṭisaṅkhāya pisuṇaṃ vācaṃ pajahati;
an10.167:10.3.eng: Reflecting like this, they give up divisive speech,

an10.167:11.2.eng: in the present life and in lives to come.’

an10.167:11.3.pli: So iti paṭisaṅkhāya pharusaṃ vācaṃ pajahati;
an10.167:11.3.eng: Reflecting like this, they give up harsh speech,

an10.167:12.2.eng: in the present life and in lives to come.’

an10.167:12.3.eng: Reflecting like this, they give up talking nonsense,

an10.167:13.2.eng: in the present life and in lives to come.’

an10.167:13.3.eng: Reflecting like this, they give up covetousness,

an10.167:14.2.eng: in the present life and in lives to come.’

an10.167:14.3.eng: Reflecting like this, they give up ill will,

an10.167:15.2.eng: in the present life and in lives to come.’

an10.167:15.3.eng: Reflecting like this, they give up wrong view,

an10.167:15.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, ariyassa vinaye paccorohaṇī hotī”ti.
an10.167:15.5.eng: This is the ceremony of descent in the training of the Noble One.”

an10.167:16.1.pli: “Aññathā kho, bho gotama, brāhmaṇānaṃ paccorohaṇī hoti, aññathā ca pana ariyassa vinaye paccorohaṇī hoti.
an10.167:16.1.eng: “The ceremony of descent observed by the brahmins is quite different from that observed in the training of the Noble One.

an10.167:16.2.pli: Imissā, bho gotama, ariyassa vinaye paccorohaṇiyā brāhmaṇānaṃ paccorohaṇī kalaṃ nāgghati soḷasiṃ.
an10.167:16.2.eng: And, worthy Gotama, the ceremony of descent observed by the brahmins is not worth a sixteenth part of the ceremony of descent observed in the training of the Noble One.

an10.167:16.4.pli: upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
an10.167:16.4.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

an10.168:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the noble descent.

an10.168:1.2.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
an10.168:1.2.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

an10.168:1.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

an10.168:2.1.eng: “And what, mendicants, is the noble descent?

an10.168:2.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple reflects:

an10.168:2.3.eng: ‘Killing living creatures has a bad result

an10.168:2.4.eng: in the present life and in lives to come.’

an10.168:2.5.eng: Reflecting like this, they give up killing living creatures,

an10.168:2.6.eng: they descend from killing living creatures.

an10.168:3.2.eng: in the present life and in lives to come.’

an10.168:3.3.eng: Reflecting like this, they give up stealing,

an10.168:11.1.pli: … ‘Micchādiṭṭhiyā kho pāpako vipāko diṭṭhe ceva dhamme abhisamparāyañcā’ti.
an10.168:11.1.eng: … ‘Wrong view has a bad result both in the present life and in lives to come.’

an10.168:11.2.eng: Reflecting like this, they give up wrong view,

an10.168:11.4.eng: This is called the noble descent.”

an10.169:1.1.pli: Atha kho saṅgāravo brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
an10.169:1.1.eng: Then Saṅgārava the brahmin went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

an10.169:1.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho saṅgāravo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an10.169:1.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

an10.169:2.1.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, bho gotama, orimaṃ tīraṃ, kiṃ pārimaṃ tīran”ti?
an10.169:2.1.eng: “Worthy Gotama, what is the near shore? And what is the far shore?”

an10.169:2.2.pli: “Pāṇātipāto kho, brāhmaṇa, orimaṃ tīraṃ, pāṇātipātā veramaṇī pārimaṃ tīraṃ.
an10.169:2.2.eng: “Killing living creatures is the near shore, brahmin, and not killing living creatures is the far shore.

an10.169:2.3.pli: Adinnādānaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, orimaṃ tīraṃ, adinnādānā veramaṇī pārimaṃ tīraṃ.
an10.169:2.3.eng: Stealing is the near shore, and not stealing is the far shore.

an10.169:2.4.pli: Kāmesumicchācāro orimaṃ tīraṃ, kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇī pārimaṃ tīraṃ.
an10.169:2.4.eng: Sexual misconduct is the near shore, and avoiding sexual misconduct is the far shore.

an10.169:2.5.pli: Musāvādo orimaṃ tīraṃ, musāvādā veramaṇī pārimaṃ tīraṃ.
an10.169:2.5.eng: Lying is the near shore, and not lying is the far shore.

an10.169:2.6.pli: Pisuṇā vācā orimaṃ tīraṃ, pisuṇāya vācāya veramaṇī pārimaṃ tīraṃ.
an10.169:2.6.eng: Divisive speech is the near shore, and avoiding divisive speech is the far shore.

an10.169:2.7.pli: Pharusā vācā orimaṃ tīraṃ, pharusāya vācāya veramaṇī pārimaṃ tīraṃ.
an10.169:2.7.eng: Harsh speech is the near shore, and avoiding harsh speech is the far shore.

an10.169:2.8.pli: Samphappalāpo orimaṃ tīraṃ, samphappalāpā veramaṇī pārimaṃ tīraṃ.
an10.169:2.8.eng: Talking nonsense is the near shore, and avoiding talking nonsense is the far shore.

an10.169:2.9.pli: Abhijjhā orimaṃ tīraṃ, anabhijjhā pārimaṃ tīraṃ.
an10.169:2.9.eng: Covetousness is the near shore, and contentment is the far shore.

an10.169:2.10.pli: Byāpādo orimaṃ tīraṃ, abyāpādo pārimaṃ tīraṃ.
an10.169:2.10.eng: Ill will is the near shore, and good will is the far shore.

an10.169:2.11.pli: Micchādiṭṭhi orimaṃ tīraṃ, sammādiṭṭhi pārimaṃ tīraṃ.
an10.169:2.11.eng: Wrong view is the near shore, and right view is the far shore.

an10.169:2.12.pli: Idaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, orimaṃ tīraṃ, idaṃ pārimaṃ tīranti.
an10.169:2.12.eng: This is the near shore, and this is the far shore.

an10.169:3.2.eng: who cross to the far shore.

an10.169:4.1.eng: When the teaching is well explained,

an10.169:4.3.eng: are the ones who will cross over

an10.169:4.4.eng: Death’s dominion so hard to pass.

an10.169:5.2.eng: an astute person should develop the bright.

an10.169:5.4.eng: for the seclusion so hard to enjoy,

an10.169:6.4.eng: should cleanse themselves of mental corruptions.

an10.169:7.1.eng: And those whose minds are rightly developed

an10.169:7.6.eng: they are quenched in this world.”

an10.17:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, you should live with a protector, not without one.

an10.17:1.2.eng: Living without a protector is suffering.

an10.17:1.3.eng: There are ten qualities that serve as protector.

an10.17:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti, pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
an10.17:1.5.eng: Firstly, a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an10.17:1.6.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti …pe… samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu,

an10.17:1.7.eng: This is a quality that serves as protector.

an10.17:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu bahussuto hoti sutadharo sutasannicayo, ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ abhivadanti, tathārūpāssa dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.
an10.17:2.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, rehearsing them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.

an10.17:2.2.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu bahussuto hoti …pe… diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā,

an10.17:2.3.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

an10.17:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto hoti kalyāṇasahāyo kalyāṇasampavaṅko.
an10.17:3.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has good friends, companions, and associates.

an10.17:3.2.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto hoti kalyāṇasahāyo kalyāṇasampavaṅko,

an10.17:3.3.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

an10.17:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu suvaco hoti sovacassakaraṇehi dhammehi samannāgato, khamo padakkhiṇaggāhī anusāsaniṃ.
an10.17:4.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is easy to admonish, having qualities that make them easy to admonish. They’re patient, and take instruction respectfully.

an10.17:4.2.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu suvaco hoti …pe… anusāsaniṃ,

an10.17:4.3.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

an10.17:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yāni tāni sabrahmacārīnaṃ uccāvacāni kiṅkaraṇīyāni, tattha dakkho hoti analaso tatrūpāyāya vīmaṃsāya samannāgato, alaṃ kātuṃ alaṃ saṃvidhātuṃ.
an10.17:5.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is deft and tireless in a diverse spectrum of duties for their spiritual companions, understanding how to go about things in order to complete and organize the work.

an10.17:5.2.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yāni tāni sabrahmacārīnaṃ …pe… alaṃ kātuṃ alaṃ saṃvidhātuṃ,

an10.17:5.3.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

an10.17:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammakāmo hoti piyasamudāhāro, abhidhamme abhivinaye uḷārapāmojjo.
an10.17:6.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant loves the teachings and is a delight to converse with, being full of joy in the teaching and training.

an10.17:6.2.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammakāmo hoti piyasamudāhāro, abhidhamme abhivinaye uḷārapāmojjo,

an10.17:6.3.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

an10.17:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu āraddhavīriyo viharati akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadāya, thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu.
an10.17:7.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant lives with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They are strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.

an10.17:7.2.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu āraddhavīriyo viharati akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadāya, thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu,

an10.17:7.3.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

an10.17:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti itarītaracīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārena.
an10.17:8.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is content with any kind of robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

an10.17:8.3.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

an10.17:9.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satimā hoti paramena satinepakkena samannāgato cirakatampi cirabhāsitampi saritā anussaritā.
an10.17:9.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is mindful. They have utmost mindfulness and alertness, and can remember and recall what was said and done long ago.

an10.17:9.2.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satimā hoti paramena satinepakkena samannāgato cirakatampi cirabhāsitampi saritā anussaritā,

an10.17:9.3.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

an10.17:10.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā.
an10.17:10.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

an10.17:10.2.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā,

an10.17:10.3.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

an10.17:11.1.eng: You should live with a protector, not without one.

an10.17:11.2.eng: Living without a protector is suffering.

an10.17:11.3.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, dasa nāthakaraṇā dhammā”ti.
an10.17:11.3.eng: These are the ten qualities that serve as protector.”

an10.170:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the near shore and the far shore.

an10.170:1.2.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak. …

an10.170:1.3.pli: katamañca, bhikkhave, orimaṃ tīraṃ, katamañca pārimaṃ tīraṃ?
an10.170:1.3.eng: And what, mendicants, is the near shore? What is the far shore?

an10.170:1.4.pli: Pāṇātipāto, bhikkhave, orimaṃ tīraṃ, pāṇātipātā veramaṇī pārimaṃ tīraṃ.
an10.170:1.4.eng: Killing living creatures is the near shore, mendicants, and not killing living creatures is the far shore.

an10.170:1.5.pli: Adinnādānaṃ orimaṃ tīraṃ, adinnādānā veramaṇī pārimaṃ tīraṃ.
an10.170:1.5.eng: Stealing is the near shore, and not stealing is the far shore.

an10.170:1.6.pli: Kāmesumicchācāro orimaṃ tīraṃ, kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇī pārimaṃ tīraṃ.
an10.170:1.6.eng: Sexual misconduct is the near shore, and avoiding sexual misconduct is the far shore.

an10.170:1.7.pli: Musāvādo orimaṃ tīraṃ, musāvādā veramaṇī pārimaṃ tīraṃ.
an10.170:1.7.eng: Lying is the near shore, and not lying is the far shore.

an10.170:1.8.pli: Pisuṇā vācā orimaṃ tīraṃ, pisuṇāya vācāya veramaṇī pārimaṃ tīraṃ.
an10.170:1.8.eng: Divisive speech is the near shore, and avoiding divisive speech is the far shore.

an10.170:1.9.pli: Pharusā vācā orimaṃ tīraṃ, pharusāya vācāya veramaṇī pārimaṃ tīraṃ.
an10.170:1.9.eng: Harsh speech is the near shore, and avoiding harsh speech is the far shore.

an10.170:1.10.pli: Samphappalāpo orimaṃ tīraṃ, samphappalāpā veramaṇī pārimaṃ tīraṃ.
an10.170:1.10.eng: Talking nonsense is the near shore, and avoiding talking nonsense is the far shore.

an10.170:1.11.pli: Abhijjhā orimaṃ tīraṃ, anabhijjhā pārimaṃ tīraṃ.
an10.170:1.11.eng: Covetousness is the near shore, and contentment is the far shore.

an10.170:1.12.pli: Byāpādo orimaṃ tīraṃ, abyāpādo pārimaṃ tīraṃ.
an10.170:1.12.eng: Ill will is the near shore, and good will is the far shore.

an10.170:1.13.pli: Micchādiṭṭhi orimaṃ tīraṃ, sammādiṭṭhi pārimaṃ tīraṃ.
an10.170:1.13.eng: Wrong view is the near shore, and right view is the far shore.

an10.170:1.14.pli: Idaṃ kho, bhikkhave, orimaṃ tīraṃ, idaṃ pārimaṃ tīranti.
an10.170:1.14.eng: This is the near shore, and this is the far shore.

an10.170:2.2.eng: who cross to the far shore.

an10.170:3.1.eng: When the teaching is well explained,

an10.170:3.3.eng: are the ones who will cross over

an10.170:3.4.eng: Death’s dominion so hard to pass.

an10.170:4.2.eng: an astute person should develop the bright.

an10.170:4.4.eng: for the seclusion so hard to enjoy,

an10.170:5.4.eng: should cleanse themselves of mental corruptions.

an10.170:6.1.eng: And those whose minds are rightly developed

an10.170:6.6.eng: they are quenched in this world.”

an10.171:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, you should know bad principles with bad results.

an10.171:1.2.eng: And you should know good principles with good results.

an10.171:1.3.pli: Adhammañca viditvā anatthañca, dhammañca viditvā atthañca yathā dhammo yathā attho tathā paṭipajjitabbaṃ.
an10.171:1.3.eng: Knowing these things, your practice should follow the good principles with good results.

an10.171:2.1.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, adhammo ca anattho ca?
an10.171:2.1.eng: And what are bad principles with bad results?

an10.171:2.2.pli: Pāṇātipāto, adinnādānaṃ, kāmesumicchācāro, musāvādo, pisuṇā vācā, pharusā vācā, samphappalāpo, abhijjhā, byāpādo, micchādiṭṭhi—
an10.171:2.2.eng: Killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct; speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; covetousness, ill will, and wrong view.

an10.171:2.3.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, adhammo ca anattho ca.
an10.171:2.3.eng: These are called bad principles with bad results.

an10.171:3.1.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, dhammo ca attho ca?
an10.171:3.1.eng: And what are good principles with good results?

an10.171:3.2.pli: Pāṇātipātā veramaṇī, adinnādānā veramaṇī, kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇī, musāvādā veramaṇī, pisuṇāya vācāya veramaṇī, pharusāya vācāya veramaṇī, samphappalāpā veramaṇī, anabhijjhā, abyāpādo, sammādiṭṭhi—
an10.171:3.2.eng: Avoiding killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct; avoiding speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; contentment, good will, and right view.

an10.171:3.3.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, dhammo ca attho ca.
an10.171:3.3.eng: These are called good principles with good results.

an10.171:4.1.eng: ‘You should know bad principles with bad results.

an10.171:4.2.eng: And you should know good principles with good results.

an10.171:4.3.pli: Adhammañca viditvā anatthañca, dhammañca viditvā atthañca yathā dhammo yathā attho tathā paṭipajjitabban’ti,
an10.171:4.3.eng: Knowing these things, your practice should follow the good principles with good results.’

an10.171:4.4.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttan”ti.
an10.171:4.4.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.”
